citation.article-title: Phylogeny of species in the family Neisseriaceae isolated from human dental plaque and description of Kingella orale sp. nov.

p.s: Description of Kingella orale sp. nov.
Kingella orale (o.ra'le. L. adj. orale, oral, pertaining to the mouth)
The description below is based in part on our previous data (2,3).
Rods or coccobacilli approximately 0.6 to 0.7 μm in diameter by 1 to 3 μm long with rounded ends.
Cells can form pairs or chains.
Cells have monopolar fimbriae up to 10 μm long.
Gram negative, but there is a tendency to resist Gram decolorization.
Not motile by means of flagella, but cells form spreading colonies.
Aerobic or facultatively anaerobic.
The specific growth requirements of K. orale are unknown.
Growth is supported by 5% sheep blood agar supplemented with 5 mg of hemin per liter and 0.5 μg of menadione per ml in both anaerobic and aerobic environments with CO2.
Growth is also supported by Todd-Hewitt broth supplemented with 2 mg of KNO3 per ml, 50 μg of L-cysteine hydrochloride per ml, and 5 μg of hemin per ml, but the yield is low.
Does not grow on MacConkey agar.
Colonies are round with slightly irregular borders and flat to umbonate, and each colony has a granular periphery.
Colonies appear to corrode the agar surface.
Oxidase positive as determined by using tetramethyl-p-phenylenediamine.
Catalase negative.
Produces acid from glucose weakly.
Does not produce acid from lactose, maltose, mannitol, sucrose, and xylose.
Does not reduce nitrate or nitrite.
Does not produce lysine or ornithine decarboxylase, indole, or urease or hydrolyze esculin.
The habitat of K. orale appears to be human dental plaque.
The G+C content of the DNA is 56 to 58 mol%.
The
type strain is UB-38.
Description of type strain UB-38.
The phenotypic characteristics of strain UB-38T are the same as those described above for the species.
This strain was isolated as the predominant cultivable microorganism from a supragingival plaque sample from a patient with adult periodontitis.
The G+C content of the DNA is 56 mol%.

The type strain has been deposited in the American Type Culture Collection, Rockville, Md., as strain ATCC 51147 and in the Culture Collection of the University of Goteborg, Goteborg, Sweden, as strain CCUG 30450.
